Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 01:10PM Rennasus wrote: Melinda: I am a grade 1 but saw you post and wanted to comment about the "waiting" game. I was diagnosed Dec. 8 and did not have surgery until Feb 3. My mass was 3.2 cm and I am on the small-busted side. My case was presented before the tumor board at my hospital and it was determined that I needed an MRI to get a better look at the size of my mass. Well, turns out a lumpectomy was no longer an option after the MRI... my mass was right under my nipple & they would have had to remove 1/2 of my boob plus the nipple. So my surgeon said a mastectomy with recon was really the best way to go. I was completely shocked as I was mentally prepared for lumpectomy! But then, after time thinking about it, I decided if I was going to have 1 side done, I wanted both done so 1) they would match and 2) I wouldn't always be wondering if I would get BC in the other boob. (My sister had BC and a bilateral — and that was 26 years ago. I like those odds!) My point is, the waiting accomplished several things in my favor: It gave my doctors time to look at my case from all sides (and get the MRI that determined mastectomy was better than lumpectomy for me). But equally as important, it gave me time to wrap my head around what was happening! It is soooo much to digest...cancer, really? I can relate. It is shocking. By the time my surgery date came around (2 months after I received "the call"), I was mentally prepared and had the surgery that was absolutely right for me and that I knew I could live with. My advice: Try to view the waiting game as mental preparation, in the same way that athletes prepare for a race. An athlete doesn't jump into competition without first preparing himself physically and mentally; facing a cancer diagnosis is no different! PS: It's also OK to visit The Land of Denial. I could not have gotten through this crisis without frequent (and prolonged!) visitations there! ;-)

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2014 09:01AM Rennasus wrote: Hi Sarah, Great news on the B9 results! If the area is benign, there is no reason to remove it. But certainly keep you appointment and see what the breast surgeon says. Get that 6-month mammogram, and make sure they continue to refer to your previous mammograms to note any changes or distortions. THIS IS IMPORTANT FOR ANYONE WITH SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY THAT TURNS OUT TO BE BENIGN. Always get copies of your pathology report (not just the page that says it's benign, but the *full* report) and if you can, also get the mammogram films (or on a CD). That way, if you move or change doctors, you have these important documents in hand and they can more accurately interpret whatever they see ASAP. Congrats on your wonderful news!! Go celebrate! :-)

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 11:43AM Rennasus wrote: Suebee, congrats on going 19 miles solo! I have found a new appreciation for hiking by myself since BC. Really helps to promote confidence. Looking forward to your mexican lasagna recipe. My DH actually prefers Mexican to Italian Lasagna, go figure! Last night's chopped salad was awesome. I always make lots of it so we can have it for several nights, as it takes me so long to chop. Here's how I make it: 1) In a fry pan over medium heat, place asparagus spears, brussel sprouts and broccoli. Sprinkle with garlic powder, salt, pepper and a spray of olive oil. Cook 5 minutes, until fragrant and starting to brown on one side. Coarsely chop, then set aside to cool.  2) Next, chop up some romaine lettuce, spinach, carrots, red & orange peppers, mushrooms and tomatoes, and place in a big bowl. If you like garbanzo beans, add a can (drained). Add in the cooled roasted veggies and toss well. (This salad, at this point, will keep for 3 days.)  3) When ready to eat, top with diced beets and cubed avocado. You don't need much dressing (balsamic works well) because there is so much flavor from the roasted veggies. I had it for lunch without dressing but with a scoop of egg salad on top.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 01:34PM - edited May 17, 2011 08:05PM by Rennasus YEAH for last chemo day for Melanie and Barbara! Good luck! Maria: I hear you on the stress of keeping BC a secret. It has been the story of my diagnosis. But I am coming to terms with this important fact: If it causes me *more* stress to keep it a secret, I need to talk about it and tell people. Cause keeping it in is not healthy. You are in a tough situation and I feel for you. But let me share one thing. I was at the farmer's produce stand a few weeks after I had my BMX. I asked the woman who owns the place to put the produce in several bags, as I could only use one arm right now to carry it as I just had surgery. (I wasn't about to get into my BC details!) But she said, oh, did you have back surgery? I said no. She said shoulder? I said no. Then I decide, what the hell, just tell her. So I did. Guess what? She is fighting pancreatic cancer! I couldn't believe the bond that was immediately forged with that one admission. My point is, if it feels right, tell them tonight. You don't have to get into all the details. Simply say I have BC and I'm taking care of it. You never know what other people may also be going through. ;-) Ladies, DH and I are heading to Vegas tomorrow for a few days. I am excited about getting away. But now I have a cloud hanging over me. My oncologist (I'll call him onco #1) has little bedside manner. I knew this going in; he is brilliant but lacking in social skills. He staged me at Stage 1B because even though my mass was 3.2 cm, it was a Grade 1 tumor, slow-growing. He said Tamox, no chemo. I was good with that! I removed both my breasts to reduce my risk and was willing to take Tamoxifin but I was *not* willing do chemo if the risks outweighed the benefits. Onco #1 felt there was no statistical benefit to chemo for me. He gave me an Rx for Tamox and said to see him in 6 months. Then I started reading on here how women have blood tests to check their liver on Tamox and if they are metabolizing Tamox properly. Hmmm. Onco #1 had said nothing about this. I asked my primary care doc about it; he said not necessary. Hmmm. So I got a referral for a 2nd opinion to a different onco. The appt. was this morning. I think you know where this is going. Onco #2 said, "You are Stage 2A [not 1B like onco #1 said]. I would never have given you an Oncotype test in the first place; your mass was over 2cm, putting your at Stage 2. The Oncotype Test is only for Stage 1 cancers only." Then he continues: "Breast cancer is a systemic disease; if it goes to other parts of your body, you will die from breast cancer. If you do chemo now, you have a shot at getting rid of the cells that may be floating around." I said well, isn't that what I'm taking Tamox for? He said yes, tamox is a very important drug. But if you catch the cancer early [which I did], you should do chemo early." Well I suspect he would say the same thing if I caught my cancer later, right? Onco #2 then asked me who my first onco was. (Onco #1 is well-known in my area.) Onco #2 said, "Oh, you're seeing Dr. D.? I'm surprised he didn't tell you you needed chemo!" Oh brother. My DH warned me that chemo is how onco's make their money. DH is not keen on chemo. His first wife did chemo right out of the gate, had a recurrence within a year, then 2 more recurrences before she passed away. It is a tender subject. There are no guarantees, I know that. Every case is different; I know that too. I also know that I have to do what I feel deep down is best for me. Maybe going away is the thing I need to digest all this...

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 12:38PM Rennasus wrote: Shannon...I can hear the anxiety in your words, g-friend, and just want to send you a big cyber hug! Though I'm far from being on the other side of this BC escapade, it *does* get less stressful. The key, for me, is to not let my thoughts take me beyond today. Pre-BC, I never really lived "in the moment," but BC has taught me that I have to take life day-by-day or I will drive myself bonkers. When I stay in this moment, I do not feel anxiety. When I find myself worrying about the future — will my incision will ever heal? Will I be able to get fills without springing a leak? Will I have to live with TE's until 2012? Will my cancer return? — I stop myself from thinking that far ahead. I can spin out thinking about the what if's. The nighttime is the worst time for me; I can't control my thoughts as well when I am laying there trying to fall asleep. Thank goodness for Xanax is all I can say! Suebee, I think people take their cues from us. We "look" good and don't complain or talk about "it" unless asked and so people think we are fine and therefore everyone just goes back to life as they know it. No one can understand our situation who hasn't walked in our shoes. That's why we have to be a little squeaky wheel and ask for what we need, even if only from just one friend.  Maria, so glad your rash has faded! I was worried about that. And you survived the MIL BBQ! YAY! It blows me away how some of the people closest to us can hurt us the most by not acknowledging our situation in any manner. I have a couple of close family members who know me well but have never asked me anything to my face, ever, about how I am doing or feeling. Zip. They have never even sent me a card. They ask DH how I am but they don't speak to me directly about it. I don't get it. Obviously they feel so awkward about it they can't get past it. So I no longer expect them to say anything (and they don't). And I am no longer disappointed (most of the time!) Annie, your line "off to bed to have some night sweats" had me howling!!! I can so relate. A funny thing has happened with the Tamox. The first 2 months, if I took a few sips of wine, I could feel it right away. So I stopped having any if we went out. But last night, we went to a birthday party with our group of friends and I had 2 glasses of wine before I realized everyone around me was tipsy except for me! I didn't feel a thing! Anyone else on Tammy notice this?

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 08:31PM Rennasus wrote: Maria, Redsky, wow those are some heavy discussions with your DHs. BC really tests us on so many levels. It just plain ole SUCKS. I have to admit I have not talked to my DH about anything other than my incision healing. We have not had any tension yet about this, tho I'm sure we will. I feel so "behind" in this process. I have not taken reconstruction as far in my head as you all have. It's like I am glimpsing my future reading your posts. Thank you for being so candid.  Did I ever tell you guys that a friend of a friend had BMX with recon 2 years ago and I got to see her in person a week before my BMX? When I saw her result (first recon implants I had seen since I wasn't yet on the pic forum), I was freakin' AMAZED at the wonders of science. Was she perfect? No. Did she have setbacks? Yes. She had scars. She had some dimpling. She even had a pucker in one of them and was considering a revision. But she was a DD, and she looked like she had REAL BOOBS, and in clothes she did not even look like a DD! She was very normal looking.  Had I not been able to see what a recon looked like in person, on a real woman, I don't think I could have gotten through this process. The image of how great she looked keeps me focused. No one tells us what a ^&%$-ing nightmare this is. Certainly not our PSs!! I guess there is a reason they are all so cagey when talking about "next steps" and what lies ahead. If they really told us, we'd all run screaming from their offices. I went into reconstruction with blinders on and very little info but with a good outcome image in my head. And my experience thus far has been pretty horrible. I even told my BFF that if I had known what lay ahead of me, I don't know if I could have done it. But, I'm in it now, so have to soldier on. Blech.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 06:15PM Rennasus wrote: Hi ladies, you all sound so good today! That is wonderful. I was sitting in the oncology waiting room today (waiting to see my Onc. doc to get my oncotype score and find out if I need chemo or not) when my husband asked if I was OK. I said, "I can handle anything he has to tell me." And that is because of all you ladies on this board who have gone through chemo or are going through it. I felt like I had a huge support group that had my back. I did not feel alone. I just wanted to give you all a shout out and a thank you!!  As for my Oncotype score, it was 16... the high end of the low-risk group. Given my age (52), peri-menopausal status, tumor grade (1), Stage (1B) and the fact that I had a BMX, my doc said statistically there was no benefit to me having chemo. So he handed me an Rx for Tamoxifen and told me to see him in 6 months. My husband was SO relieved! And you would think I would be too. But you would be wrong! I was unable to allow myself to fully feel the power of that diagnosis. I have been suppressing so many fearful and negative emotions since my journey began that when I hear good news, my reaction is still one of denial. Crazy isn't it? I should be thrilled that I don't need chemo!  The main reason I can't relax is because of the delayed healing of my incision. Another tiny opening appeared along my incision line yesterday that has me additionally worried. I feel like my body is letting me down and I have no control. I just hope I can make it to surgery on Monday without the gap getting any bigger.   Thanks for letting me vent, ladies. I think I just need to process everything that has happened this week and put it all in perspective. A nice long walk tomorrow will help.

Ladies I have decided to stick with my original oncologist and his firm recommendation of Tamox only. Here's how I look at it. I was willing to reduce my risk by having a bilateral mastectomy. I was willing to reduce my risk by taking Tamox for 5 years and then Arimidex for 5 years. Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 01:28PM Rennasus wrote: Oh my, I can't keep up with this thread!. When i wake up in the middle of the night (and I always do with my hot flashes), now I know I have something to look forward to reading! HELLO to all and GOOD LUVK on E-DAY today, Annie! Check in when you can. I have more pain today than yesterday. Mostly at the drain site but also the incision site.  I am on the Vicodin and Colace and also taking Tylenol which is helping. I cannot shower until I see PS on Tuesday. (Only below-the-waist shower only.) I am already sporting that familiar "eu du mastectomy" smell... you know the one. It's a combo of that yellow-staining antiseptic skin cleaner, my sutures healing (I hope!), surgical gauze and tape, a big ole Ace bandage, summer sweat and, the big stinker, my drain and bloody bulb. I'm sure this is also the featured perfume of E-Day Exchange as well (aside from the drain et al if you were lucky!) When I got home yesterday I sat at the edge of the pool and put my legs in. (It is so hot here the pool water is 89 degrees. That is a dreamy temp for me. i like it warm.) To my surprise, I immediately started to cry. I wanted to go swimming. But when I didn't stop crying, i realized i was finally grieving the loss of my boobs. I know a lot of women come out of BMX and MX with TEs that don't have many ccs in them yet (and some for a variety of reasons don't have TEs placed yet or at all). In those cases I imagine the grief hits when you first glimpse your flat chest. because my PS filled me to 350ccs on each side at the time of my BMX, when I looked at myself post-surgery i was only slightly smaller than i was before. I didn't have nipples but that didn't bother me. I actually was please with the way I looked. So in effect I kinda "avoided" the whole grief thing (aside from one meltdown in the hospital when I first got to my room after the BMX). Anyway, there I sat with my feet in the pool and it triggered a meltdown (and I haven't even been able to look at myself yet; that will happen Tuesday when PS takes off the bandages). I guess I was long overdue. I put my feet in the water again this morning...same thing happened. Tears started to flow.  Guess I should just stay completely out of the pool!

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2011 11:24AM Rennasus wrote: MDG, So sorry to hear you are having TE issues too. I am curious if it is what I have been going through. I had a very small dot in the center of my incision that was pale yellow, and it has been slowly getting bigger. The color remains the same... a pale yellow/green. It is NOT infected. The skin is thin. I have been doing the bactriban/Xeroform/ gauze thing. When I saw my PS Friday and he mentioned "fixing it" if it got any worse,  I did not ask what he meant because I was afraid to hear the answer.Well now I know it. This morning his nurse called to see how it was going and so I asked her what he meant. She told me my body is trying to reject the implant. Yikes!! I had NO idea! I just thought my TE had too many cc's and was keeping the skin from healing. Oh brother. I feel really uninformed and scared. The area that is trying to heal is about a half-inch in length, 1/4 inch in height. The nurse said they have seen sooooo much worse and they feel mine will heal, but tomorrow he might have to clean it out and get rid of any skin not doing it's job. She also said this is done in the office, but that I will be "prepped" in case I need to go back into surgery. I wish they had told me how serious this was from the get-go! It is alarming to hear a month after I had revision surgery (they never told me the TE was rejecting back then) and I really, really want this to take. My other TE is perfectly fine and the skin healed wonderfully.  Anyway, majorly disappointed here; thanks for listening. I think I am going back to bed.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 07:35PM Rennasus wrote: Maria, happy to hear you are 3/4's done with Chemo! Yea! Your menu for the week sounds awesome. I love leftovers! And I had to laugh at your plan for Sat night! I had some homemade green tea at the lunch place I was at today and in the back of my mind I thought, Mmmmm, I wonder if this interacts with Tamoxifen? So I did some research and came across a 2006 study in the journal "Carcinogenesis: Integrative Cancer Research" that says it actually *helps*! So green tea it is for me now that I am on Tamox!! Here's the abstract: Combination of green tea and tamoxifen is effective against breast cancer— Epidemiologic data have suggested that green tea may prevent breast cancer. Studies in our laboratory have provided evidence that green tea extract inhibits breast cancer growth by a direct anti-proliferative effect on the tumor cells, as well as by indirect suppressive effects on the tumor-associated endothelial cells. In this study, we asked whether concurrent administration of green tea may add to the anti-tumor effects of standard breast cancer therapy. We observed that green tea increased the inhibitory effect of tamoxifen on the proliferation of the ER (estrogen receptor)-positive MCF-7, ZR75, T47D human breast cancer cells in vitro. This combination regimen was also more potent than either agent alone at increasing cell apoptosis. In animal experiments, mice treated with both green tea and tamoxifen had the smallest MCF-7 xenograft tumor size, and the highest levels of apoptosis in tumor tissue, as compared with either agent administered alone. Moreover, the suppression of angiogenesis in vivo correlated with larger areas of necrosis and lower tumor blood vessel density in treated xenografts. Green tea decreased levels of ER-α in tumors both in vitro andin vivo. We also observed that green tea blocked ER-dependent transcription, as well as estradiol-induced phosphorylation and nuclear localization of mitogen-activated protein kinase. To our knowledge, this study is the first to show the interaction of green tea with the ER pathway, as well as provide mechanistic evidence that the combination of green tea and tamoxifen is more potent than either agent alone in suppressing breast cancer growth. These results may lead to future improvements in breast cancer treatment and prevention.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 09:11PM Rennasus wrote: Ladies, I am beachside until Friday (yeah!) so will keep this brief but wanted to address the anemia thing. I became anemic in 2005 due to heavy menstrual bleeding from fibroids. (In fact my iron counts were so low I had to postpone fibroid surgery.) I actually had to have iron shots in my butt. It took me a solid year (maybe more) for my body to rebuild my iron stores, despite taking iron supplements. I felt so tired and weak! Low iron means less O2 than is required is getting to your cells and hard exercise makes the heart work much harder... I stressed my heart so much that I developed arrhythmia and needed medication. Anemia is serious business. So please take care of yourselves and rest and listen to your heart...literally and figuratively. Just some [healthy] food for thought! ;-)

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 01:13PM Rennasus wrote: My goodness it must be Chatty Cathy Tuesday! I love it! I can't possible answer you all individually, so I'm just going to ramble. Please forgive me! On the toxic sisters (or toxic anyone) topic, my analogy has always been: why do I keep going back to the well searching for water when I know the well is dry? People don't change. No, I take that back. Most people don't change, especially the ones that are wacky to begin with. As much as it hurts not to have the kind of relationship we wish we could have with certain people (especially family), it simply ain't gonna happen.  That being said, it's important to cultivate relationships with kind people whom you can trust and whom support you. But that takes energy. So, better to spend your time finding new support avenues rather than expecting people to behave differently. Another great analogy: A woman tells her therapist she is upset when her husband (an alcoholic) comes home drunk. The therapist says, "What did you expect? He's an alcoholic. That's what alcoholics do." 'nuf said. Lumps, bumps and boobies: Everyone on this board should pat themselves on the back for getting through this past month. It's been a tough one all around! And how nice to hear a plastic surgeon be so proud of his work and that one of our "own" has had the pleasure of being the recipient of said work. (Yeah, Suebee!) Suebee: I am feeling job B for you; stability, benefits, plus you are a mover (and a ta-ta shaker), so I know you'll move up that ladder if you want to. (BTW I was howling at Shannon's "take job DD"!!! You are SO funny!!) Maria, I think we may have the same mother. Same age. Love her dearly. Emotionally supportive. But not able to help out physically. She doesn't drive so I am her wheels. She too likes people to wait on her. She has a lazy streak. But, God bless her, she is not a nosy momma and she stays out of my business (she hates gossip of any kind), and she will hate you forever if you ever hurt me. (She can hold a good grudge, and I'm thankful she never holds one against her kids!) A friend of my BFF's (and mine) has Stage IIIC ovarian cancer. Last week I was talking to BFF about my TE issue. She said, "well it could be worse. You could need chemo." I know she was trying to make me feel better. But I felt invalidated, unheard, and her comment negated what I am going through. And this taught me a lesson. No matter that someone is going through, never play it down by saying it could always be worse. I went for a 1 hour and 15-minute hike this AM with 2 girlfriends and one of their husbands. He carried a big walking stick but there were no coyotes or rattlers to be found. Nice having a bodyguard though! Now onto my news. I posted more about this on the pic forum, but I woke up this morning realizing my TE was not going to heal. It's been almost 5 months. It's time. So I called my PS and I'm having surgery on July 6 to remove my right TE.  I feel so relieved that I have made this decision. I have spent too much energy on this. I gotta move forward. Posts.Content: May 31, 2011 05:55PM Rennasus wrote: Good evening ladies! Saw my PS today and he removed my blue plastic stitches (they were in there for 5 weeks!). He said the incision looks great, but he was dismayed to hear I was still having some seeping issues (including today). I told him the incision only seeps when I do too much. He said well, don't do too much. (ha!) He steri-stripped it and now I'm holding off on the Xeroform and just taping gauze pads over the steri-strips. Also am showering with waterproof bandage so no water can get in. He told me we have to keep being patient, it IS improving. Guess that is as good as it gets right now! Oh yeah, he also asked me how I liked Las Vegas. I didn't remember telling him I was going, but I told him it was great. He said how did you like the Wynn? I'm like, How did you know we stayed at the Wynn? He says you were on the 60th floor, right? Now I'm like, WHAT are you talking about?! How do you know that? He laughed and said he saw me and my husband getting on the elevator just as he and his wife and were getting off. He called out to me but I didn't hear him, and then the elevator doors closed. Whenever I see him in the office, he has a suit on; he said, "I guess you didn't recognize me in my pool shorts!" I swear I never saw him at all. I did say, "If I *had* seen you, I would have told you I had a washcloth stuffed in my bra because my incision was leaking that night!" We got quite a laugh out of it. I just told my husband the story, he couldn't believe it! It's such a small world!

Much longer than our physical selves take to heal (with me being the exception! LOL!) Maria, I definitely deserved an Academy Award for the performance I put on through the Christmas holidays! (Suzy Sunshine, everything is fine, blah, blah, blah). I completely relate! It's hard not to "act" like we are OK so our loved ones don't worry. But it also helps to check in with the younger version of ourselves (not just the adult, logical version). Because that little girl is terrified! This may sound silly, but I imagine that my younger self lives inside my heart. And I talk to her. I tell her she no longer has to feel afraid, because I will take care of her the way I take care of everyone around me. I think that is the missing link — we take care of everyone, we even take care of our "adult" selves, but deep down, WE still need nurturing. Especially at times like these. Sorry to get all sappy. I say it's time to have more FUN. Because %^$#, if you can't have fun once you know you have cancer, when can you, right?

That is definitely helping with the moddiness BUT not with the hot flashes (it is reputed to help with both). Had my pre-op today in preparation for July 6 TE removal. He has had several patients who had a rejection in just one boob, had the TE removed, healed, then it worked when they had it redone. I hope I am so lucky. My doc gave me an important piece of news today. We were going over all my recent tests and stuff upcoming (the glories of being over 50). He said I needed a colonoscopy. I said already? I just had one in october. I had polyps removed. remember? (Of course he doesn't remember, because this office is crazy busy. But I digress.) he looks up the results and says, you DIDN'T have polyps. You had a lymph node removed. WHAT? OK, so now I get scared. He told me the colon has a ton of lymph nodes and one of mine must have been slightly raised and they took it off and tested it but it came back benign and is not a polyp. "You don't need another colonoscopy for 10 years.) Well that is just the best news I have heard all year! And I told him so!! He went on to explain how marvelous and magical a system the colon is. I was definitely talking to a science geek! It was all pretty funny. Whew. Amazing what will make my day these days!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 03:09PM Rennasus wrote: Edwards750... thanks for updating us! And FAB news on no chemo for you!! Your oncotype score is nice and low too. Congrats! And I'm glad you got a good cry in. My Onco also told me they had been over-treating with chemo so this new onco test really helps. BTW, the flip side to this no-chemo coin is that we *still* have chemo in our arsenal should we (hopefully never!) need it in the future. And that really is a good thing. My oncotype score came back just last week...16. On the high end of the low-risk group but since I am Stage 1B, Grade 1, and I had a bilateral b/c of family history (and not wanting to worry in future and also wanting my reconstructed girls to match), my Onco said NO chemo, NO rads, JUST Tamoxifen for 2-5 years, then the Arimedex. yippee! I really, really wanted a super-low oncotype score and I was actually disappointed when I heard the number 16 (my DH, however, was completely relieved!!). In my heart I knew my score would not be low-low, but my head really, really wanted it to be, to remove more of my worry. Oh well, I should not complain. So many ladies on these boards would love to have such a low onco score, I should just be thankful! And I am. I had incision revision surgery on Monday, a hole opened up in my incision and would not heal. Set me back quite a bit as far as fills (so far I have had NONE and my BMX was on Feb 3! And now my right TE is half the size of the left since he had to remove more skin to re-close the incision). So I won't be looking at an exchange surgery until after the summer. ;-( Diane, let us know how your path report comes out, and continued good healing to ya!!

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 10:34PM Rennasus wrote: That is correct...the Onco scores are based on a woman being on Tamoxifen for 5 years. My oncotype score was 16. That means in FIVE YEARS (after being on Tamox that whole time), my recurrence rate will be 10 percent. So I don't *really* know what my recurrence rate is at this very moment in time... I hadn't thought of it that way before. The Onco type test came out of studies on women taking hormone therapy. My oncologist strongly feels that chemotherapy has been overused in early stage non-aggressive cancers (I had a Grade 1 cancer). I felt comfortable (and thrilled!) when he said the risk of chemo did not out weight the benefit for me. I said yes to Tamox and have been on it since March. I am NOT thrilled to be on it, but I am willing to take it. (I was not willing to do chemo.) Every case is so unique!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 02:38PM Rennasus wrote: Hi all Feb surgery gals! I am one week post-op from a BMX with immediate reconstruction using expanders. The pain has always been manageable. I took Vicodin while in the hospital and for the first few days I was home. But today (so far) I have only taken one regular Tylenol.  (The first 2 days in the hospital were the most painful part of the journey, but being in the hospital makes it easier as your needs are (mostly!) met. I got my ports out Tuesday (5 days post-op) and to be honest, that is where I feel my pain. I do not feel pain in my breasts at all! I also had my pain pack removed on Tuesday, so I was afraid my breasts would hurt. But they don't. I can feel them on my chest... a sensation, but not pain. I took my first shower yesterday and got a look at my little "mounds". It wasn't so bad. The weirdest part was how they feel... like I have two small water balloons tacked to my chest. So foreign. Wearing the constricting surgical bra helps a great deal. Hardest part to this recovery is chilling out and not picking things up. So for those heading into surgery soon, know that you will at least be able to finally get some rest! (oh the things we do to give ourselves permission to relax!) ;-)

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 11:37AM Rennasus wrote: Upcoming surgery ladies: Give your anesthesiologist a heads up (before he/she puts you under) about how sick you get post-surgery and they will give you something in the recovery room. They initially gave me Zofran after I started throwing up (I neglected to tell them beforehand how sick I get after surgery), but that didn't really help; then they gave me Ativan, an anti-anxiety med that also has an anti-nausea effect, and that ended up being what worked for me. (My husband, who is a pharmacist, tells me that nausea actually begins in the brain, not the stomach, which is why the Ativan works. It was my husband who suggested to the doctor to try the Ativan on me. And he was right! PS The last time I did laundry I put my bras in the wash and thought, I should just throw these out, I won't be wearing them again. Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 01:41PM Rennasus wrote: lifelover: I was in the same position as you... I was diagnosed Dec. 8 and had BMX 2 months later on Feb 3. Do you know what Grade your tumor is? (Grade 1, 2 or 3?) This can influence how quickly they move to get you into surgery. I had a low-grade (Grade 1) mass, so there was no rush, since I have a slow-growing cancer. I AM still waiting for my oncotype score (which I just learned this AM won't be in for another 10-14 days!), because the tissue sample was just sent out last week. This *should* have been done right after my surgery. Since I already know I have to take Tamoxifan, I too didn't understand why I wasn't put on it right from the start. But my oncologist needs to see my oncotype score first to make sure it is not high, which would mean I might still need chemo, even though I am Stage 1B and Grade 1. And I did not see an oncologist until *after* my surgery. (Which is why my oncotype test was delayed, as he was the one to request it.)   So please make sure you ask your surgeon NOW about getting your oncotype test done ASAP after your surgery so you don't lose any more time. I hope that helps! Much luck on March 31. We will all be pulling for you! PS What is TUG reconstruction? I haven't heard that term before.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 10:09PM Rennasus wrote: Hi March ladies! I'm from the February BMX group. Just wanted to hop on and say yup, the waiting is hell, but you *will* get through it and it was not as bad as I imagined! There is one thing I didn't do but you should if you can: Have someone stay overnight with you the first night in the hospital after your surgery. Or at least stay with you until midnight, then have someone else come early in the morning.  I was in recovery for 5 hours (very sick from anesthesia...if you tend to get that way too, tell the doc *before* you go under, there are many meds they can give you so you are not violently ill when you come to). My DH left at 8PM after I was settled in my room. Didn't think I needed him and he thought I would be taken care of by the nursing staff. Wrong! I could not move to reach anything...not even the call button...and was stuck in the same position for hours while in pain. Suffice to say your life will be MUCH easier if you can manage to have someone stay with you.  One more thing: I bought a terry cloth belt with pouches before I had my surgery and wouldn't have been as comfortable when I got home without it. Got it here: http://www.turnerhealth.com/ Good luck ladies! Wishing you all the best and then some! ;-)

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 12:25PM Rennasus wrote: This is a fascinating thread! I had BMX in Feb; IDC and DCIS in right breast only. I had a Grade 1 mass, 3.2 cm. No node involvement (8 removed). I am 52, perimenopausal. My first onc put me at Stage 1B. My Oncotype score was 16 — high end of low-risk score. He told me low-risk women have been over-treated with chemo and that the benefit of chemo to me does not outweigh the risk. Since I am 95% ER+/PR+ he said Tamoxifen for 2-5 years, followed by Arimidex for 5 years. I started Tamox on March 24. Eventually, my gut started telling me to get a 2nd opinion just to reinforce that I had made the right decision. So in May (almost 2 months after starting Tamox), I trotted off to see a 2nd onco who was *shocked* that I was not doing chemo! He said my tumor size was large (3.2 cm), and even though it was only a Grade 1, with NO nodes involved, I should absolutely do chemo. So what did I get for getting a 2nd opinion? Confused. After much soul-searching, I came back to my original conclusion. I was willing to remove both of my breasts to reduce my future risk; I was willing to do hormone therapy for 10 years; but I was *not* willing to do chemo for a Grade 1, slow-growth cancer. I am glad I got the 2nd opinion because it allowed me to feel committed about my decision. You really do have to go with your gut. Good luck to all of you ladies still struggling with this decision. And make sure you get your Oncotype Score; I think it is an important piece of the BC pie.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 06:45PM Rennasus wrote: I'm a little late to the party here but I am glad I found this thread! I couldn't agree more with what everyone is saying. The problem with getting seriously ill (and even though I don't "feel" seriously ill, how much more serious can it get than hearing a cancer diagnosis?) is that we want to maintain a semblance of normalcy for ourselves (so we don't go insane) and the people around us. And those people don't like change. As women, we are the glue that holds the family together. But then "The Big C" creeps in and dissolves our glue, leaving us unhinged and unable to fully care for those who depend on us. I have found the process of having cancer is very similar to grief. When my father died, I was confounded by how little support I received from many of the people closest to me. Some people never even acknowledged my loss (including my stepchildren!). I tried not to judge; I know people don't know how to deal with death, they don't know what to say, and it's the same thing with cancer. It forces people to face not just your mortality but theirs as well. The good news: Guilt is good. For me I feel guilty when I begin to mother myself instead of everyone else — I somehow feel I don't deserve it. But ladies, we DO. So the next time you feel a twinge of guilt about taking care of YOU, pat yourself on the back and congratulate yourself! We can't wait for someone else to do it. I believe that is the lesson that cancer is here to teach me: To care for myself as much as I care for everyone else. (Gotta find some silver lining, right?) Happy weekend to all!

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 06:03PM Rennasus wrote: Everyone is so right, staying busy is the absolute best way to keep your mind occupied prior to surgery! The night before my BMX, I actually went to a Jay Leno taping ... had tickets way before I knew my surgery date, and when I realized the taping was the day before my surgery, I thought, how perfect is that? So I took my Mom and my sister and we laughed the entire time. It took my mind off of what otherwise could have been a very stressful day. My hope is that everyone with upcoming surgeries can fit in a little fun beforehand ... laughter really is the best medicine! PS Don't you wish everyone's posts had "like" buttons next to them like Facebook does?
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 02:34PM - edited Mar 12, 2011 02:38PM by Rennasus IllinoisNancy, some women are candidates for one-step reconstruction and some are not. I do not know why tho! Ask your doc. There are forums on here that discuss this, look under "reconstruction." Hope that helps! Maxiey40, I edited my reply to you because I did not catch that you had to have radiation. I did not have to have radiation and that's why I awoke with mounds that were nearly the size of my old breasts. Radiation can affect the skin's ability to stretch so they can't fill until you are done with rads and they see how your skin does. Best of luck on March 22, you'll do great!
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 12:50AM Rennasus wrote: Hi Ladies! Tinaj, I'm glad you finally got your onco score! I find it so interesting to hear about everyone's different treatments. I have been puzzled by the similarity in everyone's scores and differences in treatments. So many layers go into making a treatment cake! Anyway, good for you for saying no to chemo! I am in that camp...I don't think I would do it either. But, I'm still waiting to find out if it is even going to be suggested to me. My onco score should be in at the end of the week. Finally! It took 2 weeks just for my insurance to approve it. ERGH. Results are due in exactly one month after I saw my oncologist. Good thing I had other things to occupy my worrying mind so I haven't been dwelling on it — I have delayed healing in my right incision and need a 2nd revision surgery, which will happen on Monday.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 08:20PM Rennasus wrote: Kasi, just found your thread and am so sorry you got this news. Marie above says it all. Keep breathing. This time period right now ... hte waiting, the wondering, the fear ... is the absolute worst part of this journey. Once you know exactly what you have and how you are going to deal with it, the road flattens out and you will be able to see the light at the end. I remember not being able to breath after I heard my news. I forced myself to stay in the present moment, and that is how I have been living... getting ahead of yourself is a waste of your precious energy.  Sending big hugs your way.
Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed Yet But Radiologist Not Optimistic Kasi redroks2

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 09:24PM Rennasus wrote: Hi all, I'm from the Feb 2011 mastectomy group but jumped on here tonight to see how those who went before me are faring. I had a BMX with TE and have had difficulty with my incisions healing. I am encouraged to read others here have experienced that too. I thought it was just me!  I'm having my own private pity party tonight. Anyone else want to join me? Among the things bugging me: I hate carrying around these two bricks on my chest, I hate having to wear a compression bra 24/7, I hate that I'm still sleeping on an incline, and I hate that my energy is in the toilet. Meh.
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 07:03PM Rennasus wrote: mdg: I have been following your progress on your blog (your writing is terrific, BTW! We were diagnosed on the same day so I feel like you are writing my story too!) I had never heard of cold caps and I hope you have great success with them. ibccmets: Thanks for the pillow tips! I've been afraid to sleep in any position other than on my back for fear of migrating TE's! rensmars21: Your test results all sound good, congrats!! How did you know that you needed TE revision surgery? Were you in pain? I am curious because I had incision revision surgery on Feb 19 (after a BMX Feb 3) and I have yet to get any fills.  I celebrated my one month "surgiversary" today by hiking to a place I had visualized going to as I was preparing for surgery. It felt great to stand on top of that hill and acknowledge all I had been through in the past month. Yowza. Here's to everyone's successes, no matter how small; it all counts!
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2011 01:51PM Rennasus wrote: renmars21: Thanks for the info, will keep a closer eye out for ripples, et al! JoanDavies: Thanks for the laugh and the affirmation that my TE's aren't the only ones as wide as the sky! mdg: Like you, I kept "the news"  to myself, didn't even tell  DH about my ultrasound or biopsy until the night before I learned it was cancer (Dec. 8). And like you, we kept the secret until after the holidays — didn't want to ruin everyone's Christmas. It was a struggle to put  my game face on and go through the motions of my favorite holiday knowing 2011 would be a major game-changer. Anyway, all that is to say I can relate to your story. I will learn my oncotype score next week, then will finally know my plan of attack!
